source.raw_text:
The Sandbag Get-Up (similar to a Turkish Get-Up) is a full-body, multi-planar movement building strength, stability, and endurance, working legs (glutes, hamstrings, quads), core (abs, obliques, lower back), shoulders (deltoids, rotator cuff), traps, and grip/forearms, using complex patterns like the hinge, lunge, roll, sweep, push, and stand, challenging stabilization and coordination through shifting weight. [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]  
Muscles Worked 

• Legs: Glutes, hamstrings, quads, calves (driving up). 
• Core: Abdominals, obliques, lower back (significant stabilization). 
• Shoulders: Deltoids, rotator cuff (stabilizing the weight overhead). 
• Back: Traps, erectors (supporting the spine and lifting). 
• Arms/Grip: Biceps, forearms (crushing grip, holding the bag). [2, 3, 6, 7, 8, 9]  

Movement Patterns & Phases 
The get-up progresses through distinct phases, demanding different patterns: 

1. Starting Position (Supine): Lying on your back, holding the bag over one shoulder (or chest), forming a stable base. 
2. Roll to Forearm/Elbow: Rolling onto your forearm/elbow with the lead leg bent and trail leg extended, keeping the core braced and shoulder stable. 
3. Sit-Up Transition: Driving through the elbow and heel, sweeping the back leg under to a high kneel/tall sit. 
4. Hinge/Reposition: Hinging back, placing the free hand down, adjusting the bag to a strong, stable position. 
5. Push to Stand: Driving through the heel, stepping the back leg back into a lunge, then pushing up to a standing split/lunge, then standing tall. 
6. Return: Reversing the steps back to the start, emphasizing control. [2, 4, 10, 11, 12]  

Key Benefits 

• Dynamic Stability: The shifting sand forces greater core and shoulder stabilization than fixed weights. 
• Full-Body Power: Develops strength and coordination across all planes of motion (hinging, squatting, lunging, pushing, pulling). 
• Functional Strength: Mimics real-life lifting challenges for improved athleticism. [3, 5, 8, 13]
